questions.question_text: An analyst investigates an IDS alert and confirms suspicious traffic to a known malicious IP. What Enterprise Security data model would they use to investigate which process initiated the network connection?

choices.D: Searching over All Time ensures that all relevant data is returned.
choices.B: Raw word searches should contain multiple wildcards to ensure all edge cases are covered.
choices.C: Limit fields returned from the search utilizing the table command.
choices.A: Streaming commands run before aggregating commands in the Search pipeline.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a best practice for searching in Splunk?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
It is efficient to run streaming commands before commands such as stats. The table command is not a streaming command. Usually, you should use the fields command.

A. sed is correct.

In Splunk, setting mode=sed with the rex command allows the use of sed-style substitution to replace matched patterns with specified values, such as replacing parts of a credit card number with "X". The sed mode is specifically designed for search-time string replacements and masking sensitive data.

So, the correct syntax would be:

| makeresults
| eval ccnumber="511388720478619733"
| rex field=ccnumber mode=sed "s/(\d{4}-){3}/XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-/g"

Selected Answer: C
To replace defined values with "X" using the rex command in Splunk, you should set the mode to C. mask. Using the mask mode will ensure that the credit card number is masked as intended.
Someone please verify the accuracy of this answer

While testing the dynamic removal of credit card numbers, an analyst lands on using the rex command. What mode needs to be set to in order to replace the defined values with X?
| makeresults
| eval ccnumber="511388720478619733"
| rex field=ccnumber mode=??? "s/(\d{4}-){3)/XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-/g"
Please assume that the above rex command is correctly written.
